Description: Mould-made pottery oil-lamp fragment with harnessed horse-head volute from left side of oil-lamp; originally with two nozzles. Orange-brown clay with orange-brown slip.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Roman red slip lamp of Broneer Type XXI produced in Knidos. Parallels in the British Museum (Bailey 1988, Q2688-Q2701). Description of full example in the British Museum: 'Mould-made pottery lamp with two nozzles with harnessed horse-head volutes. The discus is plain except for mouldings around the filling-hole. The shoulder is decorated with impressed palmettes. Between the discus rim and nozzle volutes are impressed ovules. At the rear is a handle-ornament in the form of a vine-leaf, with a ribbed knob; at the rear is the impressed name Romanesis; there are firing-slits in the folds of the leaf. The base-ring has internal mouldings, and concentric rings in the centre. Covered with an orange-brown slip' (Bailey 1988, Q2688, produced in Romanesis workshop c. AD 70 - 80).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.06) (Phase 3)
